questions.question_text: Which statement is true regarding the run command feature in the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Compute service?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
D incorec.Not A
You can run the command without SSH or opening an inbound port because the command is sent through the Oracle Cloud Agent. This enhances security while still allowing for remote management.

Selected Answer: A
The maximum size for a script file that you upload directly to an instance in plain text is 4 KB.
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/Tasks/runningcommands.htm

choices.C: The run command feature does not require any Oracle Cloud Agent plugins to be enabled and running.
choices.B: The run command feature is not supported on compute instances that use the Windows Server platform images.
choices.A: The maximum size for a script file that you upload directly to an instance in plain text is 4 KB.
choices.D: You cannot run commands on an instance if the instance does not have SSH access or open inbound ports.

questions.question_text:
You plan to launch a VM instance with the VM.Standard2.24 shape and Oracle Linux 8 platform image. You want to protect your VM instance from low-level threats, such as rootkits and bootkits that can infect the firmware and operating system and are difficult to detect.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
The instance is either reboot-migrated or rebuilt in place for you.

C is correct. 
If you do not proactively reboot the instance before the due date, the instance is reboot migrated for you. By default, Oracle Cloud Infrastructure live migrates the instance without sending any notification about the upcoming maintenance.

choices.C: The instance is either reboot-migrated or rebuilt in place for you.
choices.A: You will receive another notification to reboot within the next 14 days.
choices.D: You will receive another notification to reboot within the next 7 days.

questions.question_text:
You have an instance running in Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) that cannot be live-migrated during an infrastructure maintenance event. OCI schedules a maintenance due date within 14 to 16 days and sends you a notification.
What would happen if you choose not to proactively reboot the instance before the scheduled maintenance due date?
Which TWO statements are NOT correct regarding the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) burstable instances? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CE
Selected Answer: CE

Selected Answer: DE
The question asks which are WRONG.
D. The baseline utilization is a fraction of each CPU core, either 12.5% or 50%. 
E. Burstable instances are designed for scenarios where an instance is typically idle, or has low CPU utilization with occasional spikes in usage. 
https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/burstable-instances.htm

Selected Answer: DE
D and E are the correct Answers, because the question asked for wrong statements.
D is wrong because:
"The baseline utilization is a fraction of each CPU core, either 12.5% or 50%" 
E is wrong because: 
"Burstable instances are designed for scenarios where an instance is typically idle, or has low CPU utilization with occasional spikes in usage."

choices.A: If the instance's average CPU utilization over the past 24 hours is below the baseline, the system allows it to burst above the baseline.
choices.C: Burstable instances cost less than regular instances with the same total OCPU count.
choices.E: Burstable instances are designed for scenarios where an instance is not typically idle and has high CPU utilization.
choices.D: Baseline utilization is a fraction of each CPU core, either 25% or 75%.
choices.B: Burstable instances are charged according to the baseline OCPU.

discussion.content:
Premium is the IAM Identity Domain type that you should create if you want a full-featured IDaaS solution that helps you manage workforce authentication and access to all of your Oracle and non-Oracle applications.
Premium Identity Domain provides users with access to Oracle Identity Cloud Service, which is an IDaaS solution that offers identity management, single sign-on, multifactor authentication, identity governance, and integration with third-party applications. The other options are not IAM Identity Domain types that provide a full-featured IDaaS solution. References: [Identity Domains], [Oracle Identity Cloud Service]

questions.question_text:
You want a full-featured Identity-as-a-Service (IDaaS) solution that helps you manage workforce authentication and access to all of your Oracle and non-Oracle applications, whether they are SaaS apps, on-premises enterprise apps, or apps that are hosted in the cloud.
Which IAM Identity Domain type should you create?
